title: EM induction - emf for square loop in xy-plane

content.description: A square conducting loop of wire is initially in the <math alttext="x y" overflow="scroll"> <mi>x</mi> <mi>y</mi> </math>-plane with its center located at the origin. There is a magnetic field that is uniform in space, but not necessarily constant in time, that is initially described by <math alttext="vector B equals, B sub 0, end sub, times open parenthesis, i hat plus k hat, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mover accent="true"><mi>B</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>B</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle displaystyle="false"><mover><mi>i</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover></mstyle><mo>+</mo><mstyle displaystyle="false"><mover><mi>k</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> at time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>.
content.question: Which of the following would cause an <math alttext="e m f" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> to be induced in the loop of wire?

choices.label: Varying the field in time as <math alttext="vector B of t, equals B sub 0 times open parenthesis, i hat times the cosine of open parenthesis, omega t, close parenthesis, plus k hat, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mover accent="true"><mi>B</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>B</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>i</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>cos</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>ω</mi><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>k</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> while keeping the loop stationary.

Varying the field in time as <math alttext="vector B of t equals, B sub 0 times open parenthesis, i hat plus k hat times the cosine of open parenthesis, omega t, close parenthesis, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mover accent="true"><mi>B</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>B</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>i</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mo>+</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>k</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>cos</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>ω</mi><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> while keeping the loop stationary.
Rotating the loop about the <math alttext="z" overflow="scroll"><mi>z</mi></math>-axis while keeping the field constant in time.
Moving the loop in the positive <math alttext="z" overflow="scroll"><mi>z</mi></math>-direction while keeping the field constant in time.
